content: Edited to set the "little example" grid in monospace (and to fix a few other minor formatting issues).

Update:
- Kept English version only (@bbb000bbbyyy & @CGThibaud)
- Added a little draw (@pac-nam)
- Checked the tests/validators coordinates (@bbb000bbbyyy): I did not see anything wrong with any of the tests/validators :) BUT in the statement, I had reversed the 2 by mistake! I clarified this.

Thank you for your comments to improve this game!
nit: typo in the English version "your little brother *could*  have been wrong when placing the pieces".

Tests are mostly typed like A1, B2, C3. I had to watch 3 or 4 to know if letters represent columns or lines. Maybe a little draw
  ABC
1 . . .
2 . . .
3 . . .
Interesting puzzle. I'll probably approve it after some checks.

Thank you for your comment!
It is pretty clear in the statement that the letters represent the column, but I can think of how to make it more obvious.
Unfortunately, I don't have too much space in the statement since I wanted to make a French version and an English version (I find it unfortunate that it's necessary to write the statements only in English whereas the rest of the site is in French for me).
Regarding the first 6 tests (well, 3 IDE tests and 3 validators), since the grid is invalid, the shot played by the sister doesn't matter, so I always put the "simplest" shot: A1. But I can change if it feels weird.
For the rest, I tried to vary, so we have: C3, G8, J10, A6, F7, E9, B2 and D4 :)
Thanks! I just couldn't figure out how to do that :)
please consider commenting in English for all CodinGamers not understanding French.
@[CG]Thibaud is possible create different versions of the same puzzle with different languages?
Unfortunately, no. Not for community puzzles :(

Hi dude, you could actually remove the french statement. It's in french for you on the official puzzles (not the community ones) because you did setup your account as french, but the community ones are usually only in english.
Anyway, there is just one problem with your coordinates. Let's say you use (x, y), when you provide "1 to 10 horizontally and from A to J vertically" then x is supposed to be 1 to 10 and y to be A to J, but your validators/tests seem to use the contrary. Funny thing is all of them seem to work fine for both coordinates system except the last validator.

The only drawback of having statements in both languages here is the length of the statement which could scare off people.

As long as English is available, I don't mind having French too.
